From: "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Introducing a New Approach to Search: Novelty Search
	(New Paper)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=29390171; y=BCOC-uUEvqIEzmytpVMDkFNVJER0xvmZs08ZOHZ9vJ5GXtMOhgIKr3nJdZk
X-Yahoo-Profile: mattias_fagerlund

Ken, 

Looking at the picture in the paper that describes where different
novelties have ended up suggests that walls get nearly completely filled
close to the starting position, petering out significantly further away. 

The open areas are lightly filled with novelties increasing in tight spots
and decreasing further from the starting position. 

Now, if we extend that behaviour to the third dimension, which was where
my reasoning started even though I wasn't too clear about that in my
conversations, it would appear that a (sqrt(X))^3 would be close to the
expected consequence;

Walls, now areas, would be almost uniformly filled (increased from lines
to ^2). Empty areas, now volumnes, would be sparsely filled (increased
from area ^2 to volume ^3). 

That would indicate that some of the novelties would expand X^(3/2) and
some would expand X^2, which might make the resulting sum worse than
(sqrt(X))^3.

I understand your explanation that not the entire search space is going to
be searched due to the complexification nature of NEAT, but that doesn't
enter into the computation if what I say above is correct. Extending the
current behaviour in 2D (which allready incorporates the advantage you
descrive) into 3D should look similar to the 2D result, and therefore
require that many more novelties to be visited.

If some additional effect would occur making the 3D version look
significalty different from the 2D version, then all bets are off, but
speculating about that seems a wee bit... speculative?  ;)

cheers,
mattias
